revised_title: Cyanogenesis in Plants: Part II - The Great Millet, Sorghum vulgare
tldr: The authors investigate the poisonous effects of the young Great Millet plant, Sorghum vulgare, and find that the toxicity is due to the presence of a glucoside that undergoes hydrolysis, producing prussic acid. They also isolate and study the glucoside, which they name 'dhurrin.'
